Title.evidence: Individualized End-Inspiratory Pause in Prone Spinal Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients scheduled for elective prone spinal surgery were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: Patients scheduled for elective prone spinal surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to either a study group, receiving individualized EIP, or a control group, receiving a fixed EIP

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of individualized end-inspiratory pause (EIP) guided by driving pressure on respiratory mechanics in patients undergoing prone spinal surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was respiratory system compliance (C_RS) measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed in sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors, data collectors, and patients were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 18 in each group analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The study group exhibited a significant increase in C_RS (mean difference = 6 mL·cmH2O−1, p < 0.05)

Harms.evidence: No postoperative pulmonary complications were observed in either group within three days after surgery.
